name: Klára DOBREV
text: Now it's time for the debates. I would like to inform Members that in one round of this debate, one member of the political groups may speak and there will be no catch-the-eye procedure or blue card issues. Next item: Commission statement - Commemoration of the 25th anniversary of Srebrenica (2020/2705(RSP)). I will give the floor on behalf of the committee to Oliver Várhelyi.

name: Olivér Várhelyi
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, today we are remembering one of the darkest days of modern European history, and one of the most tragic crimes committed in Europe since the Second World War. In July 1995, over 8 372 Muslim men and boys were deliberately and systematically killed by the Bosnian Serb forces in the UN safe area of Srebrenica, a town that they thought to be safe in the war that was ravaging Bosnia and Herzegovina. Their bodies were thrown in mass graves, facing the ground, with their hands tied. As the last victims of Srebrenica are buried in dignity, our hearts and thoughts are once again with them and with the survivors, the families and friends. We remember and honour the victims, and we extend our sympathy to all those who are grieving. May they find healing for their enduring pain.  Europe has not forgotten what happened in Srebrenica or our own responsibility for not being able to prevent and stop the genocide. In Srebrenica, Europe failed, and we are faced with our shame. Indeed, the Srebrenica genocide remains an open wound at the heart of Europe. It continues to haunt us. It continues to remind us of our shared responsibility to prevent genocide from ever happening again. It is therefore our duty to remember Srebrenica forever.  It is also our duty to ensure accountability. Justice must be served, and all those responsible for the massacre must face the consequences of their actions. Twenty-five years on, it is more urgent than ever to end impunity for the perpetrators of war crimes. The massacre in Srebrenica was recognised as an act of genocide by two different international courts: the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in 2004, and the International Court of Justice in 2006.  These established facts about what happened in Srebrenica need to be acknowledged. Any attempt at denial and revisionism are unacceptable. Political leaders have a great responsibility in that regard. They need to choose the truth, justice and cooperation over fear and hate to overcome the tragic legacies of the past and build a brighter and prosperous future for the next generations. The leaders of the region must take full ownership and lead by example. There is no place in the EU for inflammatory rhetoric, let alone for the glorification of war criminals from any side. Political leaders must be dedicated to bring their citizens, especially young people, together around a common vision of the future, built on trust, mutual understanding and respect for one another.  Civil society’s contribution to such a future is fundamental. It plays a vital role in nurturing a democratic culture of remembrance in the Western Balkans and throughout Europe, especially for the benefit of the young generation. It is up to all of us in Europe to learn the lessons of Srebrenica. The values so brutally violated 25 years ago – the respect for human life and the respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy and equality – are now at the core of our engagement with Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens.  The Commission continues to uphold these values in its relations with all of the Western Balkan countries. Implementing the rulings and decisions of international tribunals and promoting an environment conducive to reconciliation in order to overcome the legacies of the war are key elements for all countries in the region to progress towards EU accession.  This is essentially actively promoting reconciliation at all levels to secure, for the long term, the daily life of each citizen. It also entails providing redress to victims of war crime, rape and torture, supporting the return of refugees and displaced persons, and allowing the families of missing persons to achieve closure to their grief. The European Union will continue to support Bosnia and Herzegovina to advance on its European path, establishing a society where pluralism, justice and human dignity prevail. Through the accession process, the EU will continue to accompany the Western Balkans towards reconciliation and regional cooperation to build a peaceful and prosperous future for all the people of the region.  Acknowledging our past will help us to move forward. Indeed, without reconciliation there will be no long-term peace, stability and prosperity in the Western Balkans. This is why I call on the Western Balkans to work in this direction, to heal the wounds of the past and deliver a common Europe. (Applause)

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President. Never again! Never again! Never again! I would like to dedicate this cry, this shout, this desperate message to all Bosnian citizens – with no exception of ethnicity, religion or belief – and to all European citizens that in the past have experienced the horror and the hell of genocide. To put it better: to all humanity.  The sacrifice of Srebrenica is not only the tragedy of Bosnia and Herzegovina; it is the denial of humanity. Whenever and wherever there is a genocide, a massacre, a massive and systematic killing of innocent people, there is the denial of humanity, the refusal of human dignity – there is Srebrenica. All genocides, but especially the one of Srebrenica, demand truth and justice, which are the essence of human respect. Truth is not compatible with denial. Justice is not reconcilable with impunity.  On behalf of the European citizens, who we represent, I want to show our deepest sorrow and our most profound shame to all the victims of the Srebrenica genocide, to all the survivors and families, to all Bosnians – I dare say, to all humanity. There were those directly responsible for this massacre, but the failure of the international community and of the European Union is unforgivable.  Survivors and families, you are the witnesses and the victims of the darkest instincts of human beings. Without you, and without your thirst for justice, there can be no reconciliation. But you are also the hope of a peaceful and prosperous future for Bosnia and Herzegovina, for all Bosnian citizens.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: on behalf of the S&D. Club – Dear Chairman, with deep sadness and a special rooster towards the victims, today we are talking about the greatest tragedy on the European continent since World War II - the genocide in Srebrenica.   It's been a full 25 years, but memories of the horrific scenes still live strongly within us. Five years ago, the European Parliament adopted a special Resolution on genocide in Srebrenica.   There is no consolation for those who have lost loved ones even after all these years. But just as it is important to identify the remains of victims of crime, it is equally important for their families to clearly identify the crime and the criminals. Courts in The Hague, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia and Croatia have sentenced 47 defendants to more than 700 years in prison for participating in the Srebrenica genocide.    Yes, the crime in Srebrenica is genocide and should be called that. We have rulings from the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and the International Court of Justice.   But the passage of time will only strengthen our obligation to protect victims and their families from programmed oblivion directed by political engineering. And there are such attempts and there will be more; from the awarding of the Nobel Prize to those who deny genocide to disinformation campaigns sponsored by various authoritarian regimes. We must not allow the crime to triumph afterwards. We owe this to the victims of Srebrenica, but also to the victims from Ovcara and other mass scaffolding in areas where the Greater Serbian project was leaving its criminal trail. Just defending the truth about the past opens up a better future for generations to come.    The wealth of Bosnia and Herzegovina is its multi-ethnic society. Unfortunately, the political structures created in times of war often slow down the true progress of that state. Its particularities, different nationalities, cultures and religions deserve full respect, and their equality is the best pledge for the European future in Bosnia and Herzegovina.   We owe a clear perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina's membership in the European Union to the victims of Srebrenica, but also to young people who, I believe, will live in peace and prosperity united in diversity as citizens of the European Union.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: on behalf of the Renew Club. – Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioner, 25 years have passed the most horrific war crime on European soil since the end of World War II, since the srebrenica genocide. No one, but no one, has the right to take and deny genocide in Srebrenica and relativize history. And that is why today I sincerely regret that there was no political will and courage to re-enact the resolution on Srebrenica on the eve of the 25th anniversary of this great tragedy. This non-judgment of a war crime is the great civilizational defeat of this european parliament and the least we owe to the victims and their families is a guarantee that we will do absolutely everything in our power to make sure that such horrific crimes are never repeated again.  All of us are obliged to insist on justice and reject any policy that divides, condemns, excludes. With people's lives, pain and suffering, there is no compromise and no speculation. In memory of the victims of the Srebrenica crime today I carry this Srebrenica flower, a symbol of suffering, a reminder of all the evils of extremist nationalism and the dangers of ethnic hatred, a reminder of the blackest part of European history, and I want this Srebrenica flower to be a symbol of true faith in a better present, in a healthier future in which no one will lose their lives because of their diversity, because of belonging to another faith or nation.  That is why I strongly condemn the Srebrenica genocide in July 1995 and call on you all to do the same.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, Srebrenica is the most tragic episode of the Bosnian war. On the criminal front, the penalties were heavy. At the international level, the overall responsibilities do not appear to be sufficiently clear. Finally, politically, it is notable that Serbia, which is not legally involved in this tragedy, nevertheless expressed a public apology in 2010. Similarly, the President of the Bosnian Serb Republic deplored one of the darkest pages in the history of his people in 2004. In a sign of the tensions still high, it was unfortunately by stone-throwing that Aleksandar Vusei, then Prime Minister of Serbia, was welcomed at the commemorations of July 2015.  While it will take many more years to reach a soothed memory, we must, on our side, guard ed from any risky political interpretation. Indeed, the atrocities of the war cannot justify the ostracism suffered today by the Bosnian Serb Republic, or the violations of its rights guaranteed by the Dayton Agreement. Nor do they justify a principled bias in the way of the Serbian people, whose immense toll we pay during the two world conflicts.  In particular, as we celebrate the 75th anniversary of the end of the Second World War, let us also pay tribute to the 1.7 million Yugoslavs who have fallen at the cost of europe's most spectacular resistance movements. Nor do we forget that, from the town of Glina to the Jasenovac camp, this heroic people learned, before so many others, the meaning of the word genocide. The memory of Srebrenica must today be that of the thousands of victims and their families who still live today filled with memories of a loved one, a husband, a brother or a father whom, for some, they will never have known. Engraved in blood, it must also be that of these murdered men and women bruised beyond national and partisan divides.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which On 11 July 1995, 25 years ago, Bosnian Serb troops captured the town of Srebrenica and murdered more than 8 000 Bosniak men and boys.  This genocide, this genocide in the heart of Europe, took place under the eyes of world public opinion, and we must keep asking ourselves the question: how could this be possible? This failure weighs on the European Union as the greatest political failure after the Second World War. We therefore take the anniversary as an opportunity to commemorate the victims of this crime with shame and sorrow. However, in order to ensure that events in Srebrenica never happen again, we must remain vigilant, because 25 years after the Dayton peace agreement, hatred and nationalism are still dangerous incendiary accelerators that contribute to the division of society and the destabilisation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also of many other countries in Europe. Any political aspirations for supposedly ethnically pure areas must be unequivocally denied by the EU. The driving force behind this detailed planned crime was pure racism. This is not a Serbian or Bosnian invention. In order to deal with the past, war crimes against men, women and children must not be suppressed or denied, because they have left deep traumas. A rigorous prosecution of crimes, the consistent action of genocide denial and against the glorification of war criminals are as essential as the development of a common culture of remembrance. Different narratives and stereotypes still shape the picture of history. Education is important for sharing the knowledge, memory, and legacy of conflict with the next generation. Regional reconciliation is the key to peace and change. For many young people in particular, the EU has lost none of its appeal with its values, so the EU must support Bosnia and Herzegovina in its accession efforts and strengthen the democratic forces.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, we are commemorating the tragedy of Srebrenica 25 years ago. It is a trauma, still an open wound in the Netherlands, the largest massacre in Europe since the Second World War. The Netherlands sent Dutchbat to protect the enclave, but the peacekeeping mission was a mission impossible from the start. The UN mandate was unworkable, armaments too light and promises on air support were broken. Srebrenica was not the failure of Dutchbat, but of the international community and Dutch politics. At the time of the decision-making, I was a political journalist in the Netherlands. Many felt that we should do something in the former Yugoslavia. The government wanted it, parliament wanted it, the press supported it. However, good intentions resulted in a political wish that was militarily unfeasible: Dutchbat was also taken hostage. However, the Dutch government remained in place and did not resign until seven years later after a critical report.  Srebrenica has led to reflection and many lessons in peacekeeping missions. Today we honor our veterans and commemorate the victims of this horrific event, this genocide. It is perhaps a small consolation that General Mladić is now serving a life sentence in a Dutch prison.

text: Before I give the floor, Commissioner, allow me to open the first round of voting today before continuing the debate. We will vote on the topics on the agenda. name: Klára DOBREV
text: Thank you very much, and now I would like to give the floor on behalf of the Commission to Oliver Várhelyi to answer the questions raised.

name: Olivér Várhelyi
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for taking the time to reflect together and remember the Srebrenica genocide. Now is the time to honour the victims and express our empathy to the survivors and support their families and friends whose lives have been affected. The crime of genocide in Srebrenica must be a constant reminder that these acts must never be repeated. It should also remind us that genocide has happened not only in Srebrenica and there is no difference in genocide. Genocide is genocide. Healing starts with remembering and continues with respecting the victims.

Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – The Genocide in Srebrenica is an epilogue through the centuries-long 'resolution' of the Bosnian issue. Muslims who, as a result of their continued failure to re-sign and suppress their political subjectivity, have remained an anomaly in the processes of emancipation of European (Christian) nations or nations as a result of the continued failure to re-sign and suppress their political subjectivity. After the break-up of Yugoslavia, the political elites tackled the Bosnian issue literally by destroying part of the population of Bosnia and Herzegovina. They justified the legitimacy of their politics on the ideology of nationalism and the distorted historical constructs that favored the superiority of one ethnic and religious group to the other. The brutal destruction of more than 8372 men, boys and children has led to a clear effort to end the country's social and political pluralism. Although the Dayton Agreement prevented this to some extent, it has in no way been able to set sufficiently solid frameworks for its further development. This is precisely why (above all) the EU and European leaders are expected to unequivocally condemn genocide in the light of the achievement of inter-ethnic reconciliation and justice for the families of the victims of genocide, and in particular take a firm stance against the tendency to deny the latter. Aware of how fragile peace and stability can be, the EU must simply not allow ourselves to turn its back on a constructive debate about genocide. This is why I regret all the more regret that there was not enough political will in Parliament this time to mark the 25th anniversary with a special resolution.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. In July 1995, 50 years after Europe said 'Never Again' to the atrocities of the Holocaust, we again witnessed ethnic cleansing on this continent. More than eight thousand people were killed in a planned, systematic, bestial way.  Why? Because from the point of view of their tormentors they did not meet ethnic criteria. They were ethnically, culturally, linguistically alien. Nationalism, paying homage to the idea of an elected nation, better than others. Disagreement that distinctness – ethnic, cultural, linguistic, any other – is the value of diversity, not a threat. Xenophobia and exclusion from the community. Such attitudes, such views have such effects.  My hajmat – Silesia, knows these problems. It is a region torn apart by nation states for hundreds of years. A region that 75 years ago experienced ethnic cleansing – the Upper Silesian Tragedy.  For many years we have been weak students of history in Europe, we have repeated the same mistakes. We repeated them when we refused respect and the right to subjectivity other than us. We repeated them when we were insensitive to their sensitivity, when we did not want to recognize their right to self-delineation, to live in harmony with ourselves. It is high time to improve the grades, it is high time that this basic knowledge – that another is no worse, that diversity is a value – assimilate and today pay tribute to the victims of Srebrenica.

name: Klára DOBREV

name: Margaritis SCHINAS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, before I start, allow me to thank you for raising this important topic and for the debate we are about to have. Culture is part of Europe’s DNA. Our rich and vibrant cultural and creative scene is one of the greatest gifts Europe has to offer and it must be preserved at all costs. We all know how much the sector has suffered. The cultural and creative sectors have been hit by the pandemic in an unprecedented way. 95% of the sector are small businesses, small enterprises, independent artists and freelancers who are highly vulnerable and often work under very precarious conditions. The Commission has had a regular exchange with Member States, the European Parliament and the sector itself over these past months to come up with solutions. Let me first start by what we could call the emergency solutions. One of the first actions we have adopted was to mobilise Cohesion Policy funds to respond to the rapidly emerging needs through the Corona Response Investment Initiative. These packages provided Member States with liquidity and exceptional flexibility to reallocate financial resources in the areas of greatest need, which of course also includes cultural and creative industries. Second, another vital emergency initiative was the new instrument for temporary Support to mitigate Unemployment Risks in an Emergency, also known as the SURE programme, worth up to EUR 100 billion. This is a scheme designed to protect jobs and workers affected by the pandemic and, here again, it is for Member States to make the best possible use of this instrument and money and bring the much needed relief to creators, artists and writers. Third, we have, as you know, enacted the Temporary Framework for State aid measures to support the economy in the pandemic, and culture was specifically included as one of the sectors particularly hit by the crisis together with transport, tourism, hospitality and retail. Many Member States, if not all of them, have already used this instrument for the creative and cultural sectors. But, beyond the emergency measures we have also taken many specific actions. Some cultural actors have indeed developed their own promising initiatives to overcome the crisis and through this dialogue and synergies between Member States, the sector, the Commission, Parliament and others, we want to bring about specific initiatives. One of the best examples was the European Cultural Foundation that set up a new Culture of Solidarity Fund. Another platform for and by the sector was the so—called Creatives Unite initiative set up through the pilot project Finance, Learning, Innovation and Patenting for Cultural and Creative Industries (FLIP). This is an initiative that offers a common space for all cultural and creative sectors in Europe and beyond, giving access to a multitude of existing resources and relevant networks to work on. A few weeks ago, a conference with representatives from the Commission, the Parliament, the Council President and the sector was precisely organised through this platform of Creatives Unite. Let me now come, of course, to our flagship programme Creative Europe. There again we applied maximum flexibility within the existing regulatory context for ongoing and planned actions. We extended a number of deadlines to facilitate the finalisation of obligations under these difficult circumstances and we also planned specific measures for cinemas, for instance, with a EUR 5 million supplementary allocation of funds in the form of vouchers for cinemas most severely affected by the lockdown. And we redirected the work of the Support scheme for the cross—border dimension of performing arts works towards digital culture and virtual mobility. And beyond the Creative Europe programme we will very soon launch a targeted support to the disproportionately hit music sector through the Music Moves Europe initiative and there we plan to shift about EUR 2.5 million in this year to help the sector become more sustainable after the crisis. We are also exploring how to adapt and reinforce the cultural and creative sectors through the Guarantee Facility that would be used in a specific situation to allow for even more flexibility, credit holidays or guarantee cover to individual loss. Let me now quickly come to the recovery and the Next Generation EU chapter. As you know, next week we’re having a landmark meeting of our heads of state and government in what I want to believe would be a path towards an agreement on the much needed recovery and Next Generation EU package as proposed by the Commission. For culture and creative sectors, support will be available, not only through the Creative Europe programme, but also through other programmes, such as REACT—EU, the new Cohesion Policy, InvestEU, Digital Europe Programme, just to name a few. So, I think it should be wrong to see Creative Europe as the only pathway, the only avenue for recovery in the years to come. We have a multitude of instruments in the new package and we can use it effectively. But beyond the recovery package – and that’s how I wanted to conclude this initial presentation – one should not forget that we also have possibilities coming from different avenues, like, for example, Horizon Europe, where we have a Cluster 2: Culture, Creativity and Inclusive Society programme, which has fantastic opportunities for the sectors. And we should also keep in mind the so—called Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs), which for the first time will be dedicated to cultural and creative industries through our European Institute for Technology, based in Budapest, Madam President, if I may remind. So, all these tools will converge into having a strong new start after the difficult pandemic sectors without forgetting tourists. You remember that a few weeks ago, last month actually, we presented a comprehensive tourism and travel package and cultural tourism accounts for 40% of all European tourists, so we have to make sure that at the beginning of this summer tourist season, Europe will not lose its focus on its cultural tourism privilege. Honourable Members, Madam President, in these difficult times culture is not a luxury, it is becoming a necessity. Culture is part of our heritage. Culture is our European way of life. To preserve it, defend it and promote it, we must unite and work together to make this new future as bright as possible. I count on your support so that we keep supporting, helping, assisting our dynamic communities of artists and creators.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, thank you for fighting together for culture, for the cultural sector. It turns out it makes sense. I would like to thank the Vice-President for listing a number of activities that complement those we already know, particularly Creative Europe. I will also recall the economic importance here. The cultural sector generates between 3% and 4% of GDP in the European Union. And that doesn't count what it brings to tourism. You, Mr Vice-President, remembered it at the end, but all cultural activities, cultural monuments, concerts, festivals, all this is the goal of tourism. Without these cultural activities, there will be no tourism, which is the driver of the economy in many European countries. That is why we are working so hard to make both Creative Europe and the new Recovery Fund open to these activities.  The Recovery Fund will be a huge investment programme and it is up to the Member States to really use this programme to restore and actively exploit cultural monuments, to support the cultural sector, including independent media, the film industry, so that the real impact of the COVID-19 crisis is somehow replaced because it is destructive. And we know it. If the Creative Europe programme does not increase significantly – and we want you to support this again at European Commission level– the Recovery Fund here must be prepared to provide support in these investment activities. I would like to remind you that 2018 was a successful year for The European Cultural Heritage, which we want to see repeated. Finally, let me make one big appeal. Hagia Sofia World Heritage Site, a temple-museum that serves christians and Muslims, is at great risk here, and please act together to keep this temple-museum a museum, remain a reconciliation and a memory that they can live these religions together and protect their cultural roots.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her They were really beautiful pictures, when on the night of 22 June more than 8 000 buildings, event centres and venues were illuminated in red in many German cities. The reason for this orientation of the Night of Light, however, was less beautiful. Within a very short time, the Corona crisis has pushed the entire cultural and event industry to the abyss. It would therefore have been necessary to put the Berlaymont building on red alert. The Commission still does not seem to be fully aware of the gravity of the situation, and what you have just presented to us, Commissioner, is essentially a few drops in the ocean. Neither the Building Fund nor the EU's next multiannual financial framework really take account of the cultural and creative sectors. Apart from warm words, there is not much here. The cultural support programme is to be cut even further compared to the Commission's original proposal.  I therefore call very clearly for at least 2% of the building fund to be made available as a European bailout for culture and to commit it accordingly and not to put it in the care of the Member States. And with regard to the Creative Europe programme, we as a Parliament must continue to call for a doubling of the budget for the Creative Europe programme. Not only do we repair the damage that has been done, but let us try to create something new.

name: Laurence FARRENG
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, during the confinement, the authors and artists were there for us, to bring us dreams, escapes and smiles sometimes, even when the heart was not there. And all for free. They've been there for us, so will we be there for them? Indeed, for culture, there is urgency, it is a fragile sector, which stopped overnight. Cinemas, festivals, museums, concert halls, theatres, monuments: the first to close, they will be the last to reopen after months of losses and uncertainties. Uncertainties that the European Union has not lifted, and certainly not by announcing the paltry amounts that are allocated to the new Creative Europe programme: only 8%, while the European Parliament was calling for a doubling. It should be remembered that Europe spends only 0.14% of its budget on culture. This is a bad signal because it is obvious that cultural recovery must pass through Europe. What I am asking you to do today is for all European emergency mechanisms to be mobilised for culture: the SURE programme for partial unemployment, the next generation EU's major recovery plan to support its industries and sectors of various sizes, made up of SMEs and self-employed people and which together account for 4% of our GDP. After the emergency phase, Europe will also have to be more ambitious to show that culture is irreplaceable, to illustrate our diversity, our commitment to freedom of expression and creation. There are many avenues for cultural heritage to open up opportunities for our creators in the digital age, to launch major European co-productions, to include our cultural industries in the European Green Pact. Finally, Commissioner, let us have this ambition: to strengthen Europe, to set a course for our European values, we must ensure that culture is integrated into the dialogue with citizens in the framework of the Conference for the Future of Europe. But first, and for culture to be the future of Europe, Europe must give culture a future.

name: Gianantonio DA RE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Identity and Democracy Group, and in particular the 'Lega - Salvini premier' movement, has often been accused of wanting to destroy the European Union. That is not the case: we do not want to destroy the European Union, but to improve it.  I myself, on 26 October 2019, sent a letter to President Sassoli asking to resume the process of constituting the European Constitution. The reply I received from the President confirmed the need and the will to continue in this direction, underlining the centrality of European culture. The European Union must reform itself, or rather it must be reborn; it must not be a Europe of nations but a Europe of peoples. We remember the great Venetian people, or the Friulian, Bavarian, Catalan, Basque, Breton people and so on. We should not talk about a European culture, but about a set of cultures and peoples that make it up. The attempt to stifle and eliminate the different specificities can only lead to the inevitable failure of the European project, a failure that we do not want. Only full respect for the culture and history of individual countries will lead to a genuine European Union. A European culture can only be created by going beyond its national interests, and individual identities are in fact the added value and make Europe great and unique, with almost 500 million inhabitants. That is why European culture must become a priority within the framework of European policies and be the main focus of the future European Constitution. You cannot be a European Union without respect for rules and individual identities, without respect for the will of the people, even if this is uncomfortable for high finance and European bureaucracy.

name: Salima YENBOU
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, if I had to do it again, I would start with culture. This apocryphal phrase attributed to Jean Monnet takes on its importance at a time when we are questioning our ways of life, our modern societies, the very existence of our European Union. During the COVID crisis, culture was present in all households. During the confinement, the culture brought comfort and hope. Culture is a vital element of a society, culture expresses, represents, transcends, it is the bridge between generations, between people, between languages. She entertains, she celebrates, she imagines. From museums to theatres, from dance halls to libraries, culture brings us together. Culture is a privileged tool for mutual understanding and to overcome discrimination but also for strengthening human dignity, democracy, equality and solidarity: the founding values of Europe.  Right here, before your eyes, it is a true declaration of love that I make to culture and to those who make it live. The crisis, in the absence of a proportionate and ambitious response from our policies, has hit hard all those people who have made culture their profession: artists, authors, technicians, creators, intermittents.  For all of them, the recovery must be the T-moment when culture ceases to be a corollary to the other priorities and sectors of activity of the European Union. Culture deserves to become a priority in its own right, from a political and budgetary point of view. To not place culture at the heart of our European project of the world that we wish for our children is for sure to leave them a world of crises, conflicts and wars. In conclusion, I will repeat Olivier Py's recent words: we must seize the opportunity that is open to us, that of recreating a European project in which culture will not be a luxury but a compelling duty, so we must.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, an undeniably important debate and an undeniably important topic, because culture is at the heart of self-awareness, self-determination. That is why I would like to see, at a time like this, a serious conversation about what the European Commission should encourage. Should it continue on this dangerous and slippery path of promoting supranational cultural projects that go left and go towards cultural Marxism? Cultural projects that try to portray the European person as a person without roots, without clear national self-determination, without clear national self-consciousness, without a clear gender identity and without any cultural supports. Because, Madam President and Commissioner, I deeply believe that we Europeans owe who we are to our european origins; of our religion – most of us are Christians, whether they are Orthodox, Catholic, Protestant, but most of us are Christians; and our self-consciousness and self-determination. And when we talk about our roots, what makes us who we are, we cannot avoid, Commissioner, I am talking about Hagia Sophia. "Hagia Sophia" is unsurprisingly referred to as the mother of all churches. It is the basis of Christianity, of Eastern orthodoxy. What is happening in Turkey at the moment cannot be an internal matter of Turkey, it is a pan-European issue, a cultural issue, our question, and I ask you to put it, with all its rigour and all its sharpness. President Erdogan can no longer provoke the feelings, sensations, beliefs, religion of the Christian European peoples.

name: Niyazi KIZILYÜREK
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the future of the European Union is not only secured by the common market. Nor can the feeling of "we" or "together" be built only by profit. If there is one thing that will bring the citizens of the European Union together, it is culture and culture. Unfortunately, the European Union does not pay due attention to the field of culture. It is a fact that the field of culture was brutally hit during the coronavirus pandemic. Many Member States, like my country, Cyprus, have essentially forgotten the cultural sector and its people, who have been expecting some support for months, but are content with promises.  We call for a significant strengthening of the financial programme for culture in 2021-2027 and an adequate financial incentive package for cultural creators across Europe, an integrated design that will support cultural creation groups. Only in this way can we invest in the feeling of "we" and in the generations of the future.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, the recovery fund and the Multiannual Financial Framework must take into account the cultural dimension of the European Union. The Erasmus+ and Creative Europe programmes must achieve this increase in funding that we all want. We must also support Europe's cultural heritage, which also plays , as you said, Mr Vice-President - a very important role in attracting tourism, a sector which is now suffering so much. The Council of Europe's programme of European cultural routes is an excellent showcase of the richness of our cultural heritage. We must contribute to your financing. In particular, I would like to stress that in the coming year the first of these routes, the roads of Santiago, celebrates its Holy Year or Jubilee Year. Throughout 2021 the Xacobeo will probably be the most important set of cultural events in Europe. From the European Union we must help. The roads of Santiago are the roads of Europe. All the countries of the continent have crossed and for centuries many European citizens have made their pilgrimage through them to Compostela, thus contributing to the creation and expansion of a common European culture and also a European identity. And since I am talking about historical heritage, I am one of the question asked by my colleague, Mrs Oojdrová, about the plan to declare Hagia Sophia as a mosque.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate is very important for the future of the European cultural and creative sector, which is heavily affected by the crisis generated by COFID-19. Thousands of people working in the field have not had the opportunity or means to adapt to the changes caused by this crisis, and the solutions implemented by governments leave something to be desired. Despite the european Parliament's many calls, despite the questioning that each of us has made with the national authorities, this sector of which we are proud and which is one of the strengths of the European economy seems to be forgotten. This was unfortunately also the case in Romania, where the authorities have done nothing for the three hundred thousand people working in this field and account for around 10% of gross domestic product.  For this reason, we are calling today for a European response and clear measures to support this sector. We need to allocate 2% of the European relaunch plan to save the European cultural and creative sector, but it must also be done at Member State level. Our resolution will be a final call to save the sector. I hope that the European Executive and the Council will listen to the voice of the thousands of people who work in this field.

name: Niklas NIENASS
text: – Madam President, I am asking that this debate be extended because this is the first debate being held on the issue of culture. You are allocating 30 minutes for this, which is just a plain joke to have a decent debate. We’re not allowed to use blue cards and you’re just pulling us through here like a herd. This is just not efficient enough or sufficient enough for the very important issue that... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Thanks for the comment. That's why I'm trying to get you to stick to speaking time. Unfortunately, they do not allow it because of our technical possibilities, especially translators. We very much hope that sooner or later we can return to normal mode of operation and then we can go on and have longer discussions. Our fellow Member Nienass has the word from the Greens group. And then please, everybody, hold on for a minute.

name: Niklas NIENASS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Since the European Union has relatively limited competence in the field of culture, I would like to specialise in the Council – which today is characterised by absence. When Chancellor Merkel presented the programme of the German Presidency of the Council on Wednesday, she said exactly one sentence that had something to do with culture, namely the two hundred and fiftyth birthday of Ludwig von Beethoven.  That is why I would like to start with a quote from him: "And I must despise the world, which has no idea that music is higher revelation than all wisdom and philosophy. It is the wine that inspires new production."  Anyone who celebrates Beethoven's legacy, but does not even talk about promoting art and culture in these times of crisis, would have been punished with much contempt by the old master. Neither the Chancellor nor the President of the Commission have indicated, through words or deeds, that they understand the disastrous situation facing the European cultural and creative sector. "United in diversity" is the European motto, but this diversity threatens to disappear if the entire cultural and creative sector is not helped throughout Europe. In order to help the ministers of culture and the Heads of State and Government to get on with their heads of state and government, what this means is that we need a basic unbureaucratic income for artists. We need local cultural vouchers to boost consumption and a European social guarantee for artists.  Anyone who celebrates the legacy of a dead artist but does not fully help the living in such a crisis deserves the contempt of all artists.

name: Anne-Sophie PELLETIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, 7 million artists, workers and workers from the European world of culture, these soul inventors, in the words of Césaire, are threatened by the crisis. These women, these precarious men chaining short contracts are suspended from the announcements of the States and the Union.  At a time when cultural events are being postponed or cancelled, culture is too often the poor relation of public policy and we have seen how important it is during this containment crisis. In two months, for example, 10 million virtual visitors to the Louvre Museum.  Culture is not the promotion of the European way of life, it is a common good that builds a fairer, more tolerant society. So let us choose to make culture a response to the withdrawal of identity and the doubts that beset us. Some MPs have only identity in their mouths and we know the culture is threatened when the nationalists come to power.  We must take our responsibilities, reverse the planned budget cuts and increase the amount of creative Europe to help artists. Milan Kundera said: "Culture is the memory of the people, the collective awareness of historical continuity, the way of thinking and living". Let us now rise to the occasion by breaking the dogma of austerity and rethinking the financing of cultural creation.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, this is the first time I have been speaking in plenary since February and I would like to begin by sending my deepest condolences to the families of the deceased because of COVID-19 and also to thank all the people who work, putting their health at risk, to combat this pandemic.  Today we are here to talk about culture and the importance of this strategic sector in Europe, the figures of which and the importance of which have been mentioned in this House.  But I would like to focus on the importance of defending this culture as a European cultural identity, as Judeo-Christian values, and on the importance of the European Commission defending this European identity, defending Western values.  And we are seeing it with what is happening with Hagia Sophia, who want to declare it a mosque, or we have seen it with the attacks on monuments in Europe, promoted by totalitarian movements and promoted by those who want to attack our identity, our culture and our values.  We must therefore vindicate European culture, not only for economic value, but for the importance it has in defending liberal democracies in Europe.

name: Massimiliano SMERIGLIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, culture cannot be forgotten. The creative and cultural sectors are strategic: we need a new deal of culture, which starts from the emergencies of recent months, facts of social distancing, empty cinemas and theaters, blocked productions. Culture means content but also work, often precarious, and industrial realities. The Commission's recent proposal for the next MFF does not live up to the challenges we are facing: a doubled budget for creative Europe is crucial, Parliament will continue to demand it. With Next Generation EU you can create links with other sources of funding, promote partnerships and synergies. European cultural diversity must be at the heart of the new development model: we must work to strengthen existing programmes, such as creative Europe, and maximise recovery fund opportunities. We are waiting for concrete answers.

name: Margaritis SCHINAS
text: vice-président de la Commission. – Madame la Présidente, Mesdames, Messieurs, permettez-moi de vous dire que nous sommes en plein accord, tant sur le diagnostic de la situation que sur les actions à entreprendre pour pallier les effets de la pandémie sur un de nos secteurs les plus créatifs, les plus dynamiques, les plus liés à nos traditions, à notre diversité et à notre culture. I have also noted your concerns about the budget and the programme. You know that when it comes to discussions on the budget, these discussions are always, always complicated and complex. What I want to assure you is that what is on the table is the best possible option that we could propose under the current circumstances, and allow me to share with you my optimism that next week we will have a major historic agreement on the Recovery Package. That would be the best way to symbolise Europe’s return to kick-starting the real economy and growth and jobs.  I have also noted the traditional debate on what European culture represents today in Europe. At my hearing I also had the occasion to say that I see the richness of our culture, not the existence of a Homo Europaeus who thinks the same, does the same and imposes his or her values on everybody else. I see our European culture as a mirror, a mirror of diversity, a mirror of the richness of what Europe represents in terms of language, history, tradition, culture, literature and the arts, and this is what makes Europe unique in today’s ever uncertain, and if I may say, darker world.  I also wanted to say something about Hagia Sophia. I have noted your interest, which I share. Hagia Sophia is a symbol of inter-faith and inter-cultural dialogue. It is part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site – it’s a museum, it’s a symbol. It’s also a symbol of a city, which is in itself a symbol of what we would like to see as values prevailing in today’s world. Turkey is a founding member of the UN initiative for the Alliance of Civilizations and has already taken on important obligations in this context. So, given the global monument that it is, it is essential that Hagia Sofia maintains its current status, recognised both internationally and publicly. Otherwise that would undermine the tolerance and openness of Turkey. Let me remind you that, back in 2010, the city that hosts Hagia Sophia was a European Capital of Culture, and as the Prime Minister of Turkey at the time, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, said: ‘this is a European city with its heart, its culture and civilisation, its people, its past, its future. It has always looked towards Europe. Istanbul has shaped European culture and has been shaped by it’ – Prime Minister Erdoğan, 2010. This is the spirit that we want to hear. This is what we expect from President Erdoğan ten years on.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The debate is over.  The vote will take place at the September part-session. Written declarations (Article 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. - Dear Commissioner, Dear Fellow Members, The control of the coronavirus pandemic has resulted in an unprecedented situation: in most sectors, such as culture and education, actors have been crisised, and even in the smallest economic units of society, families. The cultural restoration of Europe must be based on traditional European Christian principles, on the creation of a society in which the individual does not work for himself, but for the sake of family and community. Within the issue of cultural diversity, the linguistic and cultural rights of self-reinforcing national indigenous regional minorities should also be raised to UNION level for the economic strengthening and retention of their identity, and the linguistic and cultural rights of autochtonous national minorities should be promoted.  I am also outraged that Germany, as the country holding the Rotating Presidency of the European Union, is concerned about the rule of law of other Member States, while in their own country in the 21st century a statue is erected of Vladimir Ilyich Lenin, whose criminal record against humanity can be classified indefinitely. This behaviour of glorifying totalitarian regimes and dictatorships must not be allowed to be part of Europe's culture.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – As a result of governments' response to COVID-19, many economic sectors are in difficulty and need support. Artists and employees of cultural institutions were also in a difficult situation. Today, therefore, we are discussing the cultural rebirth of Europe.  This is a good time to answer the questions: what is the European Union today? What are the values? How much respects the catalogue of principles created by the founding fathers: Konrad Adenauer, Alcide De Gasperi, Robert Schuman? These principles are: respect for the cultural and religious identity of nation states and respect for the principles of solidarity and subsidiarity. What is the answer? Such that Europe really needs a cultural revival. Indeed, we see that in the implementation of the great project of multi-culturalism, Europeans are expected to dissuade themselves, to support the decline of European culture, traditions and religions.  Modern "soul engineers" do not want to remember who the founding fathers of the EU were, they try to erase from the collective consciousness knowledge of their spiritual formation. This is the way nowhere, because just as only a truly Christian political thought could lead to the creation of a United Europe, only the ideas inspired by it can result in a real cultural revival.  We need to move away from the levee work of turning European identity into a ruin. The EU can only develop if it is a union of homelands, when it values the richness of its diversity, when it values its own culture and identity.

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: in writing. – Cultural and creative sectors (CCS) were hit particularly hard by this crisis, and they will also be one of the last ones to recover. Even when cultural life returns, sanitary restrictions combined with precautions taken will restrict its economic comeback, also due to the worsening economic situation and savings that households implement. According to the Commission, the CCS output gap for the whole of the EU this year could be tens of billions of euros. Despite this, the main EU culture programme, Creative Europe, despite the Covid-19 outbreak is allocated just EUR 1.5 billion and even that is a cut from the Commission’s proposal two years ago. In addition to its intrinsic value, culture also stimulates economic growth and even helps sustain other sectors such as tourism. CCS needs targeted support respecting geographical balance. Earmarking, in the form of grants, for cultural revival in the recovery plan is necessary. Guarantees are not suitable for these sectors given the sudden output loss and the high share of self—employed professionals and small enterprises. The funding should also entail support for media to address the immediate crisis facing the sector as well as to help it grow in the future.

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: in writing. – Let me recall that cultural institutions were the first to close and will be the last to recover. Advertising revenue has fallen dramatically. He stopped shooting movies and tv shows, concerts and festivals stopped. Millions of artists – most of them people with "liberal professions" – lost their income. How did the EU react? The cultural sector was the first to be hit by bureaucrats. The money from there was redirected to other programmes, and so on, as all political groups insist that Europe's culture budget be increased.  I can't understand how it still happens that culture and education are supposedly very important, but they're never a priority. On the contrary, the money is redirected to the Green Pact. That is why I am increasingly convinced that the ultimate goal is to live in Europe in time for non-uki and spiritless people who have completely merged with nature. I don't like the situation at all. The cultural sector needs to get a serious part of that $750 billion. provided for under the Recovery Plan. I want an immediate review of the erasmus+, Creative Europe and European Solidarity Corps funds, which have been reduced by people who are either not interested in culture or don't understand it.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – The Srebrenický massacre was the most horrific event in the history of Europe since the end of the Second World War. It is our duty to ensure that civilians are protected from military rampaths and to prevent any signs of potential genocide. Let us never forget the more than 8 000 people executed whose lives have been cruelly lost in a conflict that has ignited nationalist passions. May Srebrenica be a reminder of dangerous ultranationalism and xenophobia in our modern history, even close to the borders of the European Union.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: in writing. – The revised MFF proposal lacks ambition and strategic vision in relation to the cultural and creative sectors. The Commission proposal not only is far from doubling the budget of Creative Europe as requested by the EP but it even decreases the budget compared to its initial proposal from 2018. This is unacceptable for a programme that proved to be effective and with clear European added value and is seriously underfinanced. The Commission highlights that in the first quarter of 2020 the loss in turnover for the CCSs is expected to be 80% – one of the highest of all sectors. The CCS would need at least EUR 6 billion out of the EUR 750 billion of Next Generation EU to start the recovery. Therefore, why is this money needed for CCS not clearly earmarked in the proposed recovery plans? The cultural and creative sectors employ 8.4 million workers in the EU, nearly half of which are young people. We must ensure that the additional funds available under the cohesion instrument REACT—EU (EUR 55 billion) devoted to support workers in regions and sectors most affected by the pandemic reach cultural operators. There will be no real recovery for Europe if culture is left behind.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The following is the debate on the question for an oral answer to the Commission on the role of cohesion policy against the socio-economic consequences of COVID-19, presented by Younous Omarjee on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development (O-000035/2020 - B8-0000/0000) (2020/2644(RSP)).

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, dear Élisa Ferreira, ladies and gentlemen, the face of Europe is being disfigured by the COVID-19 crisis. All regions of Europe are heavily affected, unemployment has risen again, bankruptcies are multiplying, the real economy has been hit hard, no sector is spared, no region is spared and economic forecasts are rather catastrophic. This crisis is a harsh indicator of our fragilities. Europe is in this important moment when recovery is not an option, it is an imperative and, more than ever, European institutions and policies must stay the course, must keep principles and must keep the course of cohesion. In the midst of a health disaster, we must remember that the only European policy that has been able to help all Member States is cohesion policy. This was able to help to set up partial unemployment schemes for employees, to buy equipment for hospitals, to help SMEs. Both our Committee on Regional Development and the European Parliament have played their part and have lived up to their responsibilities in urgently adopting the regulations, and we have started legislative work on REACT-EU.  Here, in the plenary on Wednesday, Chancellor Angela Merkel and The President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, and all the presidents of the political groups called for a cohesion-based revival. And we are now waiting for these words to translate into action and into concrete reality. And we expect the European Council to live up to the promises and expectations at the next summit. The proposed funding, Commissioner, in the new Next Generation EU instrument is a step in the right direction, even though our Parliament was waiting for more funds. However, cohesion policy remains severely affected by the new MFF proposal and is down 12% from 2014-2020 programming. We must remember that cohesion policy plays a central role in all regions of Europe. It is a policy on the ground with a foothold in the real economy and, therefore, adequate support is absolutely necessary so as not to jeopardize its long-term objectives. Greater flexibility is expected and greater simplification, and on both of these objectives you will find us at your side to facilitate them. If, between the day of the tabling of our oral question and today, answers, it must be admitted, have been made, many questions remain topical. We will be very vigilant that the management of the 350 billion stimulus fund, through, we hope, mainly subsidies, is well aimed at the objectives of cohesion. That is why we ask you, Commissioner, what place the Commission intends to give cohesion in recovery. And, in this respect, how will the European Semester direct these funds to respect the principles of cohesion, i.e. that priority is given to regions as much less developed as to regions that have been heavily impacted by the crisis?  How, too, will the European Semester target, as part of the recovery plan, the regions, groups and sectors that need it most to ensure that the island and outermost regions are not left behind? Finally, at a time when all States are going into debt for recovery, how does the Commission envisage excluding cohesion policy spending from the Stability and Growth Pact for the period 2021-2027? And in conclusion, I will tell you, Commissioner, that we all hope for a good agreement in the Council. If this agreement were to be an agreement that satisfies Parliament, then our Committee on Regional Development and all the rapporteurs will take responsibility for a year-end negotiation, which will ensure that the year 2021 is not lost.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for your invitation today. You gave me a vote of confidence in the past to work for stronger economic, social and territorial cohesion in our Union, and to support the regions in facing the challenges of today and tomorrow.  Today, these challenges are even greater. In this week’s economic forecast presented by the Commission, it is yet again clear that the economic impact of this crisis will be bigger than expected. The recovery next year will be weaker than initially foreseen. The downside risks are considerable. Divergence, asymmetry and fragmentation still hang over our Union.  It is a critical moment, then. Will we, collectively, find the political will and demonstrate the leadership to put an ambitious European recovery plan into action? Half of the work is done. The European Commission has put an unprecedented ambitious recovery package on the table. Most importantly, it has put cohesion and solidarity at the heart of its package. This House was crucial in reaching this point. Thank you to all of you.  The two resolutions, supported by a large majority of the political forces, have called for a bold proposal. There may still be issues to fine-tune, but this is part of the democratic process. The crucial thing is that institutional negotiations cannot linger. We must strike an agreement on both recovery instruments powered by the Next Generation EU under the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027 in full respect of the Community method.  We must understand that every day lost without action is a life, a job, a business lost without concrete support. As you correctly mentioned – et merci de l’avoir fait – cohesion is essential to counter the emerging disparities across and within Member States, to guarantee the level playing field essential for the internal market to function, and to provide the investments needed for the green and digital recovery.  We were quick to act. We acted with the support of Parliament and of the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) and the Committee on Budgets (BUDG). The two Coronavirus Response Investment Initiatives enabled mobilisation of some EUR 50 billion of cohesion funds. This has allowed us to buy masks and ventilators, to keep people in jobs, to give cash-starved businesses a lifeline, and to give liquidity support to squeezed public budgets.  This was an emergency. However, more is now needed. Overall, the recovery package brings EUR 100 billion in addition to the cohesion funds. Half of this will come from REACT-EU: a EUR 55 billion instrument to provide immediate and flexible support in 2020, 2021 and 2022 for health, small and medium-sized enterprises, workers, and green and digital projects. It comes on top of the current and the next MFF and acts as a bridge between the two periods.  The other instrument, the Just Transition Fund, on which Parliament was also very active and vocal will now deliver some EUR 40 billion for those people and regions that will suffer the most from the transition to a carbon neutral economy. We also proposed a EUR 10 billion mid-term top-up in 2024 to capture the long-term effects of the crisis at regional level. In 2021-2027, cohesion policy should continue to deliver on its Treaty objectives to promote convergence and support the least-developed parts of the Union, and it will have the task of putting the European priorities in action on the ground in every region, ensuring a green and digital transition that leaves no one behind. However, it can only do that with a stable financial framework in place. Therefore, we need a decision at the European Council in the next few days and an agreement with Parliament right after. I will do my utmost to work with you, with the Member States, with regions, with civil society, to get an agreement on the several cohesion proposals on the table. We have to make sure that cohesion policy continues to deliver – now, tomorrow and in the long-term. For the sake of a resilient and fair recovery and for the sake of a stronger Union. Thank you. I look forward to the debate and our continued work.

name: Mircea-Gheorghe HAVA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Chancellor Angela Merkel recently stressed the importance of concern for Europe's cohesion as one of the fundamental priorities of the German Presidency of the European Council. In order to maintain and strengthen our cohesion, we need to strengthen Europe's most important investment policy – cohesion policy. Otherwise, we will soon end up talking about Europe's corrosion policy. Europe's benchmark test is to get better together, both ourselves and our economies. If we cannot now truly stand in solidarity in the face of the death and suffering of our fellow human beings, in the face of economic bankruptcy, then in the face of what should we stand in solidarity? Europe's citizens and companies are in dire need of the money of the multiannual budget, they need the money for the recovery package, which is converging with the budget. We stay away from each other, but we can no longer keep money away from Europe's pressing needs. Member States expect explicit transitional measures from the European Commission to ensure that the EUR 37 billion from structural and investment funds is absorbed. We cannot provide Europe with an inflation of financial promises and compromises on paper without real money, without properly estimated and timely revenues. Europe needs a budget now.

name: Mónica Silvana GONZÁLEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, the message is very clear: cohesion policy is not a matter of generosity, but of justice. We must harness the full potential of our regions, our municipalities, to rebuild ourselves after this terrible pandemic, as it is the most important investment for our future. During the pandemic, you said this, we have mobilized more than 37 billion euros that have maintained jobs and who have helped the people who have had the most difficult jobs: groups of people with disabilities, groups of the elderly, the homeless, in metropolitan areas, in rural areas. It is the real Europe, it is the nearby Europe that we want, not the Europe that defends tax havens. We have many projects pending to relaunch Europe, and to do so we must ensure that cohesion allocations in the period 2021-2027 will be used in direct investments and will not be used in direct investments linked to COVID. We want a cohesion policy that focuses on reducing inequalities and prioritizing territories, prioritizing municipalities so as not to leave anyone behind and not to put conditionality. That is why we are very hopeful that the Council will reach a good agreement and, with its impulse, this will be possible so as not to leave anyone behind.

name: Susana SOLÍS PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, this pandemic has been an unprecedented challenge for the institutions. It has made us clear by the many shortcomings, but if there is one thing we can be proud of, it is that Europe has been able to react.  The largest recovery plan ever presented in Europe has been launched, with solidarity and cohesion at the heart of this plan. And if in the emergency the role of cohesion policy was important, in overcoming the new funds will be essential. Our concern is that they reach citizens as soon as possible, simplify them, have the flexibility they have never counted on, and that bureaucracy be eliminated.  But this crisis must also make us think about the fate and use of these funds. Because these funds are the opportunity that our autonomous communities, our municipalities, our peoples have to carry out reforms that lead us to a more digital, greener and more sustainable model; that make our SMEs, our trade, our companies, our tourism much stronger and more competitive, and being clear about what our priorities are and what Europe we want.  I want a Europe that is much closer to citizens, that invests in education for young people, but also for those who work and have to recycle; a Europe where rural areas are not emptied, but are attractive to young people and families; a Europe where the digital divide does not exist; a Europe with a digital and agile administration, with liveable cities; a Europe without inequalities and that leaves no one behind. This Europe is possible if we all work for a much stronger, much more ambitious and much more modern cohesion policy.

name: Alessandra BASSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about policies for social cohesion and for the good of the peoples of Europe, we cannot but remember what has just happened and what is still happening with regard to the economic and social crisis caused by the coronavirus. Many words and proclamations, but so far few actions. It's better to promise little and do what I promised than to make big announcements. More flexibility is needed, and only in this way will it be possible to smooth out the gap and encourage détente leading to greater equality. We need more investment that can bridge the social gaps in certain regions, protecting and promoting local specificities and identities, and that can foster rapprochement and cohesion. That is the challenge facing the European Union and let us see if it will be able to meet it. I hope that the sad lesson of COVID has served, otherwise European social cohesion will deteriorate to a point of no return.

name: Niklas NIENASS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Ferreira for coming here to us today. I think we have all seen that we needed to take very swift measures in order to help the regions, and I think we did so very well by using three one and two, or three one and plus. But now I think we are in a different stage and we need to follow a good procedure in order to help the most. This procedure, as always, is to evaluate the previous measures, define what we want to achieve and then rethink how we achieve it the best. Therefore I have questions for you. For the evaluation, we know that 60 regions have already applied to change to amend the operative programme and therefore we want to see is there a correlation between those who are using the flexibility measures and those regions affected most by COVID. Are these measures that we have taken actually using them, helping them?  My second question: when we want to achieve something for the future we need to take a strategic approach, and therefore I want to ask you, how can we define a strategic approach and how can we ensure it then in REACT-EU, to actually have the strategic approach where I think less flexibility and more – sorry I’m missing the words here – but you know what I mean, that this is needed, very much.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, the economic and social consequences of coronavirus are dramatic, and especially in those countries such as mine, Spain, where mismanagement has multiplied its devastating effect. In the European response to the crisis, the Cohesion Funds are vitally important in eliminating inequalities and supporting an economic recovery that will undoubtedly be very long and very complex. We are pleased that the Commission has adopted our idea that Member States can transfer funds between programmes. However, there are still two to-dos. With regard to the coherence and simplification of the different existing mechanisms, the Transitional Fund cannot replace the Cohesion Funds, but complement them in very specific aspects. And secondly, with regard to the budget. Many colleagues have said this before this morning: an ambitious cohesion policy, more important than ever at the moment, needs no cuts, but a budget that meets the needs.

name: João FERREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, in response to the consequences of COVID-19, the European Commission has proposed that structural and investment funds be used, so far with the mesmenda few resources that have previously existed, in some cases diverted from projects where they are certainly lacking.  In its proposals for a financial framework, the Commission set out a path of continued weight reduction of cohesion policy in the overall budget. In this way, the asymmetric impacts of the integration of the single market and the common policies of the single currency will certainly be accentuated and, instead of the promised convergence, what reality will bring to us, as it is bringing, is more divergence between countries. The additional from the Recovery Fund referred to here, either because of the summarising amounts involved or, above all, because they constitute transfers on account of future payments, do not substantially alter this reality and may even aggravate it in the long term. What we need is more and no less cohesion, more and no less structural funds, more and no less support for the productive sectors, employment and environmental protection. More and no less flexibility is needed in member states' use of cohesion funds.  European co-financing, European co-financing rates, needs not to be raised and not reduced. It is necessary to permanently eliminate constraints such as the Stability Pact, at least to the minimum, excluding from its application the expenditure associated with the mobilisation of cohesion funds. It is necessary to introduce a dimension of cohesion into centralised management programmes in all programmes, for example in science, the environment and other areas, and it is necessary to bring them to a shared management logic.  Commissioner, you don't lack paths. The European Commission does not seem to be very interested in going through them, unfortunately.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is still a lack of data, but experience tells us that an economic crisis such as the current one will increase the profound economic inequalities in our society. This was the case with the crisis that began in 2008, and it does not matter whether the financial markets or a virus are the source: the most vulnerable always take the worst part. The objective of cohesion policies is economic and social convergence between the different regions of the Union, but at a time of crisis this convergence stops. It is essential to adapt the rules of the Structural Funds to every economic context: when member states' tax revenues fall dramatically, how can we make the allocation of these funds conditional on the same cofinancing criteria that we are asking for in a situation of growth? Yes to greater flexibility and simplification, yes to an emergency reserve, no to diverting these funds to other purposes, yes to excluding them from the Stability Pact. Let us adapt cohesion policies to the current crisis environment in order to combat effectively the economic inequalities that put the health of our democracies at risk.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Mr President-in-Office! Without a successful cohesion and agricultural policy, Europe would be very different. The differences would be even greater. Europe's countryside would be even less populated, without much-needed municipal and environmental infrastructure.  Covid crisis has shown that living in the countryside in a green environment with clean air, forests nearby, a garden next to a house can be of better quality than on the tenth floor in a million-dollar city. In such an environment, it is easier to maintain health as well as a state of mind in the mind.  The conditions for the creation of quality jobs are built infrastructure, including high-quality broadband connections, which today unfortunately only accessible to half of the population of the European countryside. Broadband connections enable modern jobs in agriculture, forestry, crafts, distance work, distance learning, online shopping.  And that is why I believe that, even in the period ahead, when we have new funds, the European Union will use these billions to build and improve the situation in The European countryside, strengthen the smart villages project and build a resilient, digital and green European Union.

name: Hannes HEIDE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Regional policy is at the heart of the European Union, just as cultural and educational policy should be its brain. It will make Europe felt in our home communities and in our home cities. It is more than remarkable that more than a third of all jobs created in the last funding period are due to regional policy.  Our regions face major challenges. This crisis cannot be overcome with the best of intentions without committed cohesion policy. The new tasks and challenges, indeed necessities, cannot be met without adequate financial resources. In an ambitious EU budget, the regional development funds must be significantly upgraded and increased. Only then can we successfully address the important future issues such as digitalisation, climate protection and crisis management. Yes, this is a question of solidarity, but above all of reason, because the benefits and added value for all Europeans are clearly visible. Any better equipping of regional policy increases economic growth, creates jobs, increases the credibility of the European Union and thus guarantees our common future in a united People's Europe.

name: Stéphane BIJOUX
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this morning, right now, one of the territories most affected by COVID-19 is an overseas French territory on the doorstep of Brazil, French Guiana. European Guiana is facing an appalling health crisis. In fact, in 48 hours, the French Prime Minister and the Minister of Overseas Affairs will go there to strengthen the protection of the population, but Europe must also intervene.  Of course there is the rescEU system, of course we have to intervene, but we also need to consolidate and support local solutions: regional authorities and SMEs need them. You have to trust the experience and expertise of the field. Everything must be done to fight the virus, but we must also fight against the feeling of abandonment against COVID-19.  Everywhere in Europe, we need a solidarity response and the answer, the solution, we have it: it is cohesion, cohesion between the territories, cohesion among all Europeans.
