So flexibility, simplification, responsiveness, all these crisis management tools must be consolidated and they must become the rule, the rule of building a useful and united Europe.

name: Robert ROOS
text: – Mr President, this spring, tyre manufacturer Apollo Vredestein announced a mass redundancy in the Dutch city of Enschede, with 750 jobs lost. After 110 years, production will be transferred to Hungary, where Vredestein commissioned a modern factory in 2017. Two weeks ago it became clear that the European Cohesion Fund had been used to build the M3 motorway around that plant. Without this highway, Vredestein would never have moved. A disastrous method of using EU subsidies to lure companies away.  What will happen if the EUR 750 billion recovery fund is approved? According to the plans, this will cost the Netherlands 31 billion euros, 4 000 euros per household. Hungary receives 7.3 billion euros. Will this buy away even more jobs in the Netherlands? The Netherlands is always called to show solidarity within the EU. That means the "ATM." But now the Netherlands is funding its own demolition. Who else is in solidarity with the Netherlands within the EU?

name: Simone SCHMIEDTBAUER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As a former mayor, I know what is being done every day in our regions and communities. With a lot of passion, passion, love and hard work, my colleagues all over Europe are trying to lay the foundations for a home and to counteract the exodus. But they need support for that. The framework conditions must be right – and the financial resources.  That is why I still find it incomprehensible that you are still not prepared to put forward proposals for a transitional period. We must not leave any regions in Europe behind. That is what it boils down to if we do not finally act. We must tackle fundamental problems such as cutting red tape in a determined manner. The flexibility of the Corona investment initiatives has helped, but may have been only the beginning.  That is why I would ask you to ensure that 'the regions of Europe – the backbone of our society' do not remain an empty lip service by acting quickly.

name: Cristina MAESTRE MARTÍN DE ALMAGRO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, a few months ago, when we did not even know about the existence of COVID, we were here discussing the possibility of a more ambitious Financial Framework. We were on alert to the threat of reduced cohesion funds and called for less rigidity and more flexibility. Sometimes it looked like we were even asking for a chimera.  Today, however, it has been shown that it can be done if it is wanted and that it has been possible to react diligently and quickly to answer the most urgent questions. But what now? Because we are, unfortunately, at the beginning. There can still be a long way to go and the European Union cannot stay in first aid.  The message is clear: we need sufficient and fair resources to leave no one stranded and without conditionalities of any kind that reproduce the mistakes of the past. How can we guarantee both? And, not least, what will come next?  Cohesion policies are the key to the European project's vault and the principles that inspire it. This vault cannot be damaged or resented by the impact of this crisis; on the contrary, it has to be strengthened, and we will only achieve it if we are able to assign it the role, in the quality and quantity it deserves. You can count on our support to do so.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank President Omarjee for driving this debate and that this question has been presented so that we can be discussing something as important as the role of the Cohesion Funds in this post-COVID recovery process.19 First of all, I would like to stress that this Parliament and the Commission have been able to react in time. It was known to react in time and it is important to tell the citizens. Secondly, I would like to applaud the ambitious plan that the Commission has presented— Next Generation EU — where we are talking about 750 billion, which come from the taxes of European citizens, who are going to address cohesion policy in this post-COVID era. Thirdly, I wanted to focus on the importance of this money being spent and used in those regions that have been most affected by the COVID crisis. And that must be important: you must go to those regions that are most affected. And secondly, we need to rethink the priorities so that they are aimed at the most important objective, which must be job creation, wealth creation. It is small and medium-sized enterprises that will be able to create jobs. Therefore, we must not lose sight of the need for small and medium-sized enterprises that can benefit most from these funds to be approved in the Next Generation EU.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank everyone for the support given to the Commission in all the different moments and difficult moments that we have been going through. First of all, I would like to start by quoting what Mr Heide mentioned, that the Cohesion Policy is the beating heart of Europe. I think it is, and I think it was beating when Europe was in trouble, when Europe was suffering. Et je vous remercie, Monsieur Omarjee, de votre référence au travail qu’on a fait ensemble pour avoir une réponse immédiate au problème du coronavirus. I would like also to say that, in fact, this opportunity, for all those that mentioned that there was really the need to go to specific situations, to the people, that in fact these flexibilities that became available in the context of the response by the Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative (CRII) and CRII+ have already been used by almost all EU Member States. For the time being, all Member States, with the exception of Austria and Denmark, have been using these transfers, this possibility to use the available funds – a maximum of over EUR 50 billion – in order to pay what has been paid: the masks, the ventilators, the support jobs and to support small and medium enterprises and to give an immediate answer. So, for all those that used to say that the Cohesion Policy is an old policy, I think we have proven that it is quite alive and quite capable of delivering emergency aid when it is needed. Actually, with State aid it was almost the only financing policy. I mean it’s not the only one, but it is the biggest one, and the most visible one. My second point is on the quality of what we have proposed. Yes, we had to propose a long—term kind of action that combines a short—term instrument, REACT—EU, with all the flexibilities and keeping the possibility of a co—financing of up to 100% if Member States so decide. Of course, for practical reasons REACT—EU cannot be distributed immediately by the Commission at the level of each region because we are distributing the envelope on the basis of actual data, and by the end of the summer we will not have the data at the regional level. But it is up to the Member States to transfer the same criteria that for the Commission is the drop in GDP, drop in growth, the increase in unemployment, including youth unemployment, and the relative prosperity of the country in order to have a follow—up, a bridge to the next Multiannual Financial Framework that really can help the regions to bridge these differences. But we hope and we are very attentive to the quality and the criterion that Member States will be using in this distribution. (I am also trying to answer your question, Mr Omarjee.) Having said this, I would just like to add that, yes it is important that we now take the Commission’s proposal as the real basis. I think we should stop saying that there is not enough money, I think there is a lot of money and here I quote Mr  Nienaß and others: we have got to see what we want to do with this money and the quality of what we’ll be doing, because the quality of what we’ll be doing determines our future. Sendo assim, e em particular para o Sr. Ferreira que referiu a potencial quebra de fundos, não há quebra de fundos.  Os fundos do MFF têm, neste momento, de ser contabilizados com os outros instrumentos adicionais que estão a ser propostos pela Comissão e eles são, de facto, 55 mil milhões de euros para o REACT-EU, um extra de 32,5 mil milhões de euros para o fundo de transição justa e um valor de 10 mil milhões de euros que virão no ano de 2020 a ser distribuídos de acordo com os dados efetivos de quebra de rendimento e aumento de desemprego das regiões da Europa. Portanto, são mais 100 mil milhões de euros.  Penso que, neste momento, o que importa é que, rapidamente, nós tenhamos uma clara ideia e uma clara capacidade de organizar o que queremos fazer, de fazer e organizar o modo como se pode fazer a implementação na prática e no bom sentido das oportunidades que estão a ser criadas.   I’m very proud that the Commission was so blunt and so strong in this proposal. This could only be done because you were here and you were putting on pressure. This could only be done because also, at the level of certain governments, there was this impulse for us to act.  So, let’s work together and let’s very quickly decide the approval, with fine—tuning, with better quality here and there, but that quickly, we move forward so that the money is, as all of you were saying, available – with continuity, not stopping – and directed to a green, to a digital, to a modern recovery, that is shared by all the regions and all citizens in Europe.  So, this is what we have at this moment on the table. Let’s work together as institutions to deliver what the citizens are expecting us to deliver in such a critical and difficult moment in the history of Europe. Thank you very much. Let’s go on working together and yes, of course, we are always attentive to the regions that are most in difficulty. We have proven it, so let’s work together and let’s help citizens wherever they are because they all need to be part of our common future.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Commissioner, thank you so much for your intervention and for your work. It is not every day that we see a Commissioner say 'there is a lot of money'.  We all look forward to the Council's decisions, but we also recall that this European Parliament has the final say and has already made clear its position in defence of cohesion policy.  I thank you all for your presence and your participation. The debate is over.  The session is adjourned until 1:30 p.m.  Written declarations (Article 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " Cohesion policy is the beating heart of Europe. Today, as never before in the history of the European Union, we must take care of this heart. Take care of those who need this help due to the effects of the pandemic especially. The need for prudence and sensitivity is not to overlook those for whom structural solutions and adequate assistance are critical. It is often to be or not to be in employment and functioning in the present reality. Because if you don't help now, when?  We should counteract the socio-economic impact of COVID-19 by drawing conclusions from the most difficult weeks and months that are behind us. We now know which sections of the economy are particularly helpful at a time of danger that have proved strategically necessary, which determine whether we can feel safe. It is also an opportunity to support those sectors of the economy that have proved so important in the pandemic, such as access to efficient internet connections for remote work, communication and coordination, not forgetting remote education, which could not have been as efficient without efficient Internet connectivity.  We must act quickly, efficiently and with care. Let us do our best to help those affected by the COVID-19 pandemic efficiently and to strengthen our countries and the European Community as a whole before the challenges ahead.

name: Mircea-Gheorghe HAVA
text: in writing. – Chancellor Angela Merkel recently stressed the importance of concern for Europe's cohesion as one of the fundamental priorities of the German Presidency at the European Council. In order to maintain and strengthen our cohesion, we need to strengthen Europe's most important investment policy - cohesion policy. Otherwise, we will soon end up talking about Europe's corrosion policy. The benchmark test of Europe's ambition is to get better together, both ourselves and our economies. If we cannot truly stand in solidarity in the face of the death and suffering of our fellow men, in the face of economic bankruptcy, then in the face of what should we stand in solidarity? Europe's citizens and companies are in dire need of the money for the multiannual budget and the recovery package. We stay away from each other, but we can no longer keep money away from Europe's pressing needs. Member States expect explicit transitional measures from the European Commission to ensure that the EUR 37 billion from structural and investment funds is absorbed. We cannot give Europe an inflation of financial promises and compromises on paper, without real money, without properly estimated and timely revenues. Europe needs a budget now. Of the 1.8 trillion euros discussed.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The coronavirus pandemic crisis has clearly demonstrated the importance and strategically needed of cohesion policy. It was thanks to this policy, just a few days after the pandemic escalated, that we were able to provide the first necessary support to extremely vulnerable local governments and businesses. It was thanks to cohesion policy that hospitals received urgent assistance at that time. Let me just remind you that eur 37 billion has been mobilised in a dozen days to support in a crisis situation.  However, I call on the European Commission and the Member States not to forget the overarching role of cohesion policy, the role of the European Union's most important investment policy, and the levelling of development of European regions in thinking about the future of cohesion policy. In the planned actions, we must focus not only on current and undoubtedly urgent responses to the crisis, but also on recovery from the crisis, when cohesion policy investments will be necessary to re-enter the path of economic growth. For this purpose, a sufficiently high budget is necessary.  I would also like to draw attention to the need for the Commission to propose a contingency plan in the event that no agreement on the new Regulations on the Structural Funds can be reached in time, so as to avoid distortions in the functioning of cohesion policy from the beginning of next year.

name: Krzysztof JURGIEL
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It should be noted that the scope of the changes proposed by the EC is insufficient in view of the scale of the challenges posed by the epidemic. It is also worth highlighting the critical decrease in appropriations for the achievement of the Treaty objectives under cohesion policy. According to the latest EC proposal of May 2018 (currently being negotiated), the PS budget under the MFF is down by 2.3% compared to the EC proposals of May 2018 (including the ERDF by 2%, ESF+ by 3% and THE FS by 1.7%).  The need for immediate implementation of the proposed actions. Therefore, key legislative initiatives: the Coronavirus Response Investment Initiative (CRII) and CRII+ should be adopted as soon as possible. It should be stressed that the willingness to cooperate constructively in the Council must be confirmed by each Member State. This will enable the rapid implementation of legislative proposals related to the economic recovery of EU countries after the COVID-19 pandemic. We should therefore mobilise efforts to achieve this objective.  I also support the increase in the possibility of transfers between cohesion policy funds (ERDF, ESF+ and SF), as well as the establishment of a set of interim measures in the implementation of cohesion policy, the extension of the existing scope of ERDF support and the extension of the ERDF specific objectives. The changes , to the extent appropriate for the ESF+, respond adequately to the social and economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and provide opportunities for a flexible and rapid response to possible future labour market crises.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Unfortunately, the long-term socio-economic impact of a long-term pandemic has become a reality and will be felt for us for some time yet. Our task now is to focus on stopping them – so that we can return to the expected normality. Cohesion policy is a very effective and proven tool for reducing socio-economic inequalities in the EU, which have intensified again in times of crisis. I am therefore convinced that it is cohesion policy that should play a key role here in europe's recovery plan. Due to the complications caused by the pandemic and the extraordinary remedial measures taken in this regard, it seems impossible to adopt all the new ESIF regulations in a timely way. I therefore call on the European Commission to introduce the required transitional provisions in order to avoid complications and further administrative burdens for Member States and their operators. I also consider it appropriate to introduce even greater simplification and procedural flexibility at least until the end of the Union's exit from the economic crisis. It should also be ensured that the measures programmed under traditional cohesion policy are not permanently redirected directly to combating the effects of the pandemic. These must therefore be new measures that will not be used to the detriment of the original objectives of EU cohesion policy. I also consider it appropriate to consider creating an emergency reserve in the event of similar events in the future.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: in writing. – This crisis has caused an unbearable number of deaths, but it has also had a brutal impact on the lives of people, families, economies and states. A crisis with global impact. Citizens expected a European response: immediate, but also a robust programme for economic and social recovery. Cohesion policy proved to be the best positioned instrument for the construction of these two responses. Responding immediately. Allowing Member States to use cohesion funds still available with full flexibility to meet the immediate demands of families, local authorities, businesses, in particular SMEs. Using existing margins to launch specific programs that strengthen health systems, health research and protect employment. Having a key role in building the European response. Increased cohesion funding via the Recovery Fund with the React-EU programme, with the addition of the 2014/2020 MFF. But also, as expected, an appreciation of cohesion resources in the next MFF 2021/2027. At the same time, cohesion policy will have to continue to contribute, and contribute more, to the digital transition, to the fight against climate change, but also to the achievement of the European Pillar of Social Rights. The demands are great. Cohesion policy has entered a new generation and will respond to new challenges.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. "Again, the most important message of the crown crisis is that we can only find answers to the challenges we face together. The epidemic has severely affected all regions of the Union. The number of patients, the number of dead, varies from region to region. But the impact on the economy is equally devastating everywhere. Member States are trying to do what they can with their money and the ability of their leaders. However, the differences are spectacular. The German, French and Austrian governments promise unlimited support. The southerners, the Slovaks, the Czechs, the Baltics are also making esteemed efforts. And there are countries where there is no substance behind promises. Since the beginning of the crisis, the Hungarian Government has vehemently denied that the European Union is providing any assistance. In the meantime, he is courting China and buying unusable buoys from them at an astonishingly expensive amount of money instead of medical aids - for the benefit of corrupt Hungarian politicians.  The only hope for my compatriots is the actions of the EU. Release of cohesion funds, a SURE fund to protect jobs and a €750 billion reconstruction programme. I call on the Commission to prioritise weaker regions in the crisis. At the same time, require the Hungarian Government to use cohesion money strictly to protect small businesses and jobs. Strictly control the content of the 2021-2027 development programmes and make sure that money is used to reach municipalities and small businesses instead of thieves. Directly from Brussels if necessary.
